Gosh...a lot of you guys are so harsh. Roughly half an hour ago, I was crying endlessly, after having a panic attack, and loosing a lot of my energy to the point where I collapsed. It was horrid- due to a mental health problem. As soon as I was stable enough to walk, my mind went to this, and I played it as quickly as I could. It was so soothing. Sure, the compound formulas are basic, but familiar, which is very nice and calming to see after being so overwhelmed. The sound, the colours, it was all so calming that soon the panic diminished, and my breathing rate returned to normal. This is a really soothing video to me, and I assure you, though it may not be your favourite video, it is useful to others, so instead of bickering on about how boring this was to you, and that it's useless, then this video just wasn’t created with you as an audience. Just as it isn’t your type of video, don't go complaining about it, for it certainly is others. Thanks Asap Science!

I am an elementary school teacher...second grade. I thought for a moment that too much pause was given from the time that you introduce the information: fuel source, oxidizing agent,heat. However, because I know that learning requires repetition and processing... what we call in the education "metacognitive processing", I found myself repeating the list until I felt I remembered it. Luckily, each time that I thought I might forget, the visual aide that helped me to say like a mantra "fuel source, oxidizing agent, heat" was still on the screen. Then as it changed to additional information about how a wood fire (which I know from extensive past experience) you added that wood only requires heat and a fuel source, I internalized that, of course, the oxidizing factor would come from the air. Quick diversion, I will spend time in graduate school writing out transcripts like this but I know otherwise it may seem out of place. To the producers of this video I want to say, I think you have hit a nice balance between informing your audience and allowing them to reflect. I hope that other educators, probably better middle and upper grades, realize you are an interesting provider of educational resources. That is all, except good work, amigos.

My grandmother is always asking me to write her a story, so I wrote her a Christmas one, while listening to this in the background, Ill tell you it,:
   
Fire.
  How can something that does not exist hold so much beauty and wonder.
It has no mass, it has no form, It has no definite shape of size, Its nothing, yet, in a way, it's everything.
You cannot hold it in your hand, but it can exist on your hand. It’s the most confusing, yet the most simple thing in the universe.
But fire is nothing but a warmth that runs through your veins.
The native americans used fire for communication, the cavemen used it for cooking, we use it, in a brick fireplace, to tell each other that everything is all right.
There is nothing to fear.
Everything is under control.
Nothing ever is in control.
Its the greatest deception, and the greatest truth.
But here we are, on opposite sides of the biggest powerhouse in the world. Facing different seas, and confronting different troubles.
Yet when I look into a fire, at the calmest of times, I look straight through the void of misery and dread, deception and lies, and I see you. My greatest reassurance. 
The gentle snapping and popping tells me that you're there, that everyone's there.
And you know what? No matter what happens, no matter what gets thrown at me, that might just be enough.
Fire.
